Award.AwardTitle: Kokes Awards for the 26th North American Catalysis Society Meeting

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal seeks funding to support graduate and postdoctoral student participation in the 26th meeting of the North American Catalysis Society (NACS) to be held in Chicago, Illinois June 16-20, 2019. The funds will provide registration fees and accommodation assistance to 38 students from U.S. universities as administered through the merit-based Kokes Travel Award program sponsored by the NACS. The students will present their research at the conference, attend lectures by leaders in the field of catalysis, and provide assistance to the organizers in running the meeting.

The biennial NACS meetings are the largest North American meetings dedicated to catalysis. Student participation helps train young researchers in this vital aspect of science and enginering that supports advances in environmental pollution control, energy utilization, sustainability and greenhouse gas reduction, and competitiveness of the U.S. chemical and petroleum industries. The Kokes Award selection committee will ensure appropriate representation of women and underrepresented groups in making their awards.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The biennial North America Catalysis Society meeting (NAM) has always been the premium scientific meeting of researchers in the field of catalysis in North America. The 26th NAM took place on June 23-28, 2019 in Chicago, IL.  This meeting provided a forum for research professionals and students to gather to share their latest findings and discuss topics of mutual interest and future directions of the field.  For students, there is the additional opportunity to participate in educational workshops on the science and technology of catalysis and practice presenting their work in front of a national audience.  Support from NSF to cover the registration and hotel accommodation enabled twenty three graduate students from U.S. academic institutions to attend the meeting.  These students were chosen competitively from a pool of three hundred and sixty two applicants.  Together with other funding supports, a total of ninety five students were supported by the Kokes Travel Award. Of the 95 students, 23 were female.  As the travel award recipients, the students were strongly encouraged to attend the pre-conference educational workshops on different topics of catalysis science and technology. During the meeting, they attended technical presentations, participated in receptions and the conference dinner, and made use the opportunity to build their professional network.  In addition, they were each assigned a duty to assist the organizers in the meeting.  The duties included: helping in the opening reception, supporting the registration and local arrangement activities, serving as ushers during plenary lectures, helpers with the poster session arrangements, or helpers for session chairs. Students were asked to indicate their preference to the assignments.  Helping with the meeting arrangements offered a chance for the students to gain some experience in organizing a medium-size meeting.  Overall, the students found the experience of attending the meeting, the oral and poster sessions, and participating in the workshops and meeting organization a very valuable educational and professional experience.
